snippet: Tokyo’s decision to no longer adhere to its plan could complicate efforts to forge a global climate change pact.
abstract: Japan backs off from pledges to slash its greenhouse gas emissions, saying shutdown of its nuclear power plants in wake of Fukushima disaster makes targets unattainable; under new goal, Japan will release 3 percent more greenhouse gases in 2020 than it did in 1990, rather than 6 percent cut originally promised; announcement casts shadow over international talks to address climate change.

byline.original: By HIROKO TABUCHI and DAVID JOLLY
byline.contributor: Hiroko Tabuchi reported from Tokyo, and David Jolly from Paris. Martin Fackler contributed reporting from Tokyo.

lead_paragraph: Tokyo’s decision to no longer adhere to its plan could complicate efforts to forge a global climate change pact.

headline.main: Japan Backs Off From Emissions Targets, Citing Fukushima Disaster
headline.print_headline: Japan Backs Off From Emissions Targets, Citing Fukushima Disaster

keywords.value: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
keywords.name: subject
